description:
Henipavirus nipahense, also known as the Nipah virus, is a zoonotic virus that belongs to the genus Henipavirus within the family Paramyxoviridae. It is a highly pathogenic virus that primarily infects fruit bats of the Pteropus genus and can be transmitted to humans, causing a severe and often fatal neurological and respiratory disease.

The Nipah virus is a negative-sense, single-stranded RNA virus with a genome of approximately 18,000 nucleotides. It is characterized by its unique ability to cross the species barrier and infect a wide range of mammalian hosts, including humans, pigs, and other domestic animals.

The virus is transmitted to humans through direct contact with infected animals, consumption of contaminated food or drink, or close contact with infected individuals. The Nipah virus can cause a range of clinical manifestations, including fever, headache, mental confusion, drowsiness, mental disorientation, mental disturbances, coma, and acute respiratory distress syndrome, which can lead to a high mortality rate.

Effective prevention and control measures for Henipavirus nipahense include early detection, contact tracing, and implementation of strict infection control protocols, as well as the development of vaccines and therapeutic interventions to mitigate the impact of this emerging zoonotic disease.
